p: Type I and type III IFNs establish the cellular state of viral resistance, as well as activate the adaptive immune responses to viruses ( Ivashkiv and Donlin, 2014). Successful viral pathogens therefore have evolved mechanisms to escape both immune recognition and suppress the functions of IFNs and ISGs. Many viral proteins are dedicated to modulating the host IFN response. These mechanisms have been extensively investigated for SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV ( Lim etÂ al., 2016, Nelemans and Kikkert, 2019, Totura and Baric, 2012). Both viral and host factors determine the outcome of IFN signaling. Type I IFN signaling in particular can be deleterious through its systemic, pro-inflammatory effects ( Ivashkiv and Donlin, 2014). Whether the IFN response has a protective or pathogenic effect in SARS and MERS seems to be dependent on the context in which IFN signaling is induced.
